title.narrative: 1.4 H&N: IMPROVED INCLUSIVE AND EQUITABLE ACCESS TO QUALITY MATERNAL, NEWBORN

description.narrative: 1.4 Improved\202Finclusive and equitable\202Faccess to\202Fquality\202FMaternal,\202Fnewborn, adolescent\202Fhealth by\202Fadopting\202Fthe Every\202FNewborn Action Plan (ENAP)\202Fwith continuity between community,\202Fprimary and secondary healthcare services\202Fand\202Fintegrated mental health services provision at the level of PHCs, which contributes to Child Health, Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition, Evaluation, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Health And Emergencies, Health Systems Strengthening, Health â€“ General, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Infant And Young Child Feeding, Maternal And Newborn Health, Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being, Nutrition And Emergencies, Nutrition In Early Childhood, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women, Nutrition â€“ General, Research, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Data, Research, Evaluation And Knowledge Management, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: 1. By the end of 2022, most disadvantaged children have access to enhanced health and nutrition practices2. Sustained use of safe water supply and sanitation services, and adoption of hygiene practices, by children and their families in poor communities vulnerable to climate change, conflict and public health emergencies.

title.narrative: 1.4 Improved202Finclusive and equitable202Faccess to202Fquality202FMaternal,202Fnewborn, adolescent202Fhealth by202Fadopting202Fthe Every202FNewborn ActionPlan (ENAP)202Fwith continuity between community,202Fprimary and secondary healthcare services202Fand202Fintegrated mental health servicesprovision at the level of PHCs

description.narrative: UNCEF is contributing to strengthening the health system especially the maternal and newborn health services in the country through partnership with MOPH. UNICEF worked with MOPH to enhance MNCH services through contributing to the development and implementation of the Long-Term Plan for subsidization of PHC services, working on enhancive newborn data and services and partnering with private sector. This is in addition to the community outreach services including community-based midwifery services and caregiver’s education on integrated MNCH package for more than 434,568 caregivers of children Under 18 and referral of 117,437 children and adolescents to enhanced MNCAH and immunization services. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:18/12/2021
